awd_titl_txt: MSB-FRA: Testing abiotic drivers of activity, abundance, and diversity of ground-dwelling arthropod communities at a continental scale
awd_abstract_narration:
Insects are among the most abundant and ecologically important animals in the biosphere. They include serious crop pests and invasive species that cause millions in damage. A key goal of this project is to understand how and when the number, and activity of insects change as one moves from place to place across the U.S., and why those numbers fluctuate from year to year.  Such an understanding can help predict insect pest outbreaks, the spread of invasive species, and changes in an ecosystems ability to provide food and fiber and conserve soil nutrients. This project will use insect samples collected by the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) at 47 locations spanning the U.S.'s major ecosystems to determine how abundance, activity, and diversity of soil insects vary across the U.S.  The project will use environmental barcoding (analyzing insect DNA from the samples' preservative) and image analysis techniques to  train computer algorithms to count and identify insects preserved in the samples. Together, these technologies will automate and streamline NEON's monitoring network, providing the first such nationwide dataset on abundance, activity, and diversity of the U.S.'s soil insects. In doing so they will serve a variety of stakeholders: ecologists testing and refining models that predict future insect communities; land managers who want to know the likelihood of a pest eruption; conservation biologists and urban planners hoping to anticipate spread of invasive ants and beetles.
 
A key aim of this project is to quantify and predict how Earth's great abiotic drivers--temperature, precipitation, and biogeochemistry--govern how ecological communities of soil insects vary from place to place. Community data at continental extents vastly underrepresent the terrestrial arthropods in part due to the immense effort required to count, size, and identify taxa ranging from mites to ants to beetles to spiders. Yet the few existing arthropod datasets suggest that as one travels from deserts to rainforests, terrestrial arthropod communities vary by orders of magnitudes in abundance (the number of individuals), size (mass per individual), activity (the rate at which individuals do work on the system), and diversity (the number of species/forms). Combined, these four variables help predict how arthropods regulate ecosystem processes like decomposition, herbivory, and seed dispersal. This knowledge gap will be filled by the analysis of samples from the NEON pitfall network (arrays of traps, sunk in the soil, that capture and store biweekly samples of arthropods in ethanol). It will develop two complementary methods to do so. Environmental Bar Coding samples and identifies pitfall taxa from extracts of ethanol. Image Analysis uses machine learning to count, size, and classify arthropods in a sample. Pitfall samples containing key orders of Earth's arthropods will be analyzed from NEON's 47 sites, and Environmental Bar Coding and Image Analysis pipelines that count, size, and identify taxa from these samples will be developed, tested, honed, and validated, and then used to analyze two years of NEON samples.

por.por_cntn:
Most of Earth’s animal biodiversity—the number of species that can be found in a given space and time—is known for large animals like mammals and birds. But estimates suggest that by far the greatest number of animal species are, in fact, invertebrates, mostly small to nearly microscopic animals like insects, spiders, and snails. These “little things that run the world” in the words of biodiversity scientist E. O. Wilson, exist largely in relative obscurity for two reasons. First, it is difficult to identify them, as their sheer abundance swamps the time and ability of the few invertebrate taxonomists. Second, there exist very few concerted efforts to inventory invertebrates in a standardized way.

The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) was constructed to systematically sample US biodiversity from Alaska to Puerto Rico (and Hawaii). One component of NEON is a program to capture and preserve invertebrates (henceforth “bugs”) from every major habitat in North America. These samples are archived in 50 ml tubes full of ethanol, resulting in an organic library of individual bugs, ready to be examined, counted, and identified.

 

Our project undertook the first effort to generate tools toward this end, and to use these tools to begin to quantify how the abundance and diversity of invertebrates varies from the arctic circle to the American subtropics. The first tool uses the DNA that leaks from the bugs into the storage ethanol. We constructed a protocol using commonly available tools of genomics to extract the DNA, quantify it, and link it to databases identifying bugs by their genetic code. The second started with a painstaking sorting of bugs onto a white background, high resolution photography, and computerized analysis of the size, abundance, shape, and color of each bug in the photo. Finally, these data were used to construct an early Artificial Intelligence model that would identify the bugs. In sum, we used both DNA and photography to develop tools that will increase the availability of these NEON pitfall trap data to other scientists.

Here I summarize two major findings.

First, we used our imaging techniques to ask how the activity of a community (say, a scrub habitat in southern Arizona, or a deciduous forest in Massachusetts) varied across the US. Note we say “activity”, because pitfall traps—cups embedded flush with the ground, filled with preservative, that captures all the bugs that wander by and fall in—don’t measure the number of individuals, but the number modified by how active they are. Put another way, these traps measure the flow of individuals across the surface of America. We found that this varies widely and tends to increase with the warmth of a site, but in ways specific to the kind of habitat: increasingly smoothly with temperature in scrub habitats, but increasing, then decreasing, with temperature in deciduous forests. One reason this is important is that NEON was built to monitor change in the numbers and diversity of these communities over time. Understanding the varying role of temperature in the bug activity in these communities is an important key for conservation biologists to determine if numbers are increasing or declining.

Second, we found that the diversity of bugs (determined by the DNA technique) in these communities formed a curious pattern rarely seen before. While it is commonly thought that the diversity of life increases as you move from the poles to the tropics, very little data from actual communities—small patches of space where the bugs are likely to bump into each other and interact—have existed. Using NEON’s extensive sampling, combined with the DNA extracted and analyzed from the preservative in their storage vials, we found that instead, diversity of invertebrate communities actually increased from Puerto Rico up to the northern tier, where it generally remained high until you reached the Arctic Circle. This suggests that something is allowing more species to coexist in cooler, more seasonal environments. We continue to work on the solution as to why.

 

In sum, our project working with NEON samples is discovering, and in some cases rewriting, the book of invertebrate ecology in the US. In doing so, we are generating new puzzles (why do communities of invertebrates seem to show different patterns at small community scales from the geographical patterns documented in the last century) and providing the conservation community new tools to monitor the ecological health of the little things that run the world.
